instruction: Can the remote sensing model developed using deep neural networks accurately assess lichen biomass in high-latitude ecosystems using spectroscopic methods, and how does it compare to traditional methods?
Output:
Yes, the remote sensing model developed using deep neural networks can accurately assess lichen biomass in high-latitude ecosystems using spectroscopic methods. The model was trained with 8914 field records of lichen volume collected over a period of more than 20 years. It utilizes Landsat data, including reflective bands and indices, combined with a digital elevation model, to predict lichen volume. The model achieved an R2 value of 0.57 in predicting lichen volume in an evaluation set.

In comparison to traditional methods, the remote sensing model offers a considerable improvement. Earlier methods based on specific reflectance were less efficient. The neural network model, on the other hand, takes advantage of the mixed spatial resolution input and can handle the complex spectral signature of lichens. It also considers factors such as elevation and NDVI (Normalized Difference Vegetation Index) as important predictors. Even with moderate tree cover density, the model performs well in accurately estimating lichen biomass. Therefore, the remote sensing model provides a powerful tool for assessing lichen biomass and can contribute to ecosystem and ecological research, as well as rangeland management.
